title: MIC's Olivia Bentley details her past dating struggles while coping with alopecia
text:
Made In Chelsea star Olivia Bentley has admitted she previously struggled to date as she coped with alopecia.

In November's edition of Cosmopolitan, the TV personality, 24, recalled the time an ex boyfriend told her 'I’m not going to have kids with you because you’re bald' as she reflected on feeling 'insecure' during the early stages of her health battle.

The reality star - who was diagnosed with the hair loss condition at 16 - first shed light on her battle back in May, and has insisted she now feels 'empowered' about raising awareness on the disorder.

'I'd always been self-conscious': Made In Chelsea star Olivia Bentley has admitted she previously struggled to date as she coped with alopecia

On first discovering she had alopecia, the blonde beauty revealed she was left shocked when her hair started to fall from her scalp in the shower.

The socialite said she noticed the change when she was prescribed the contraceptive pill at 16, but confessed the 'damage was already done' after she stopped taking the birth control medication.

On struggling with alopecia during adolescence, she explained: 'As a teenager, I’d always been self-conscious that I looked like a boy, and having these problems with my hair has compounded that.

'I would try all sorts of things to make sure no one knew what was happening. I’d pull the rest of my hair over the bald spot and wear hats.

'I’d cover the bald spots and wear hats': In November's edition of Cosmopolitan, the TV personality, 24, revealed she was diagnosed with the hair loss condition at 16

'He was such a p****': The reality star also recalled the time an ex boyfriend told her 'I’m not going to have kids with you because you’re bald'

'Then I tried clip-in hair extensions, which is actually one of the worst things you can do, as it can overstress the hair. Now I often wear wigs and keep it short.'

Alopecia areata, which causes baldness, is thought to be an autoimmune disorder. The immune system - the body's defense system - turns on itself.

The disorder usually affects teenagers and young adults, but it can affect people of any age. It is just as common among men as women.

'I was afraid of someone spotting it': The E4 star - who is currently in a relationship with co-star Digby Edgley revealed she was met with difficulties when she first jumped on the dating scene

Strong: Nearly a decade on from her diagnosis, she insists she can 'joke' about wearing extensions and feels more 'confident' about living with alopecia

There is no known cure, although there are various treatments which may be effective for some people.

The E4 star revealed she was met with difficulties when she first jumped on the dating scene.

'I was always afraid of someone spotting it. Dating was tough', she said. 'I was so worried that boys would run their fingers through my hair and feel it, or get caught on the extensions.'

The photographer admitted she was left mortified when a former partner claimed he wouldn't want to have children with her as she's 'bald'.

Olivia - who is now in a relationship with Digby Edgley - explained: 'A boyfriend once said, “I’m not going to have kids with you because you’re bald.” Now I’m older I’d have told him what a pr*** he was, but back then I was so insecure.'

Nearly a decade on from her diagnosis, she insists she can 'joke' about wearing extensions and feels more 'confident' about living with alopecia.

She shared: 'Now, I’ll tell people when I’m wearing a wig and joke about it. Stress can worsen alopecia, but sharing with others makes me feel more empowered.

'As I’ve got older, I’ve realised that I’m much more aware of it than other people … I just want others with the condition to feel more confident – a lack of hair does not define you. It’s so much more common than people think.'

Made in Chelsea airs Mondays at 9pm on E4.
